mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Expression Regulation of the Phospholipase A2 Gene Family in Cottonmouth Snakes (Agkistrodon Piscivorus)

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The genetic mechanisms that regulate transformation of genetic material from genotype tophenotype influence evolutionary response to environmental change and promote species diversity. Identifying molecular regulatory mechanisms that affect gene expression is challenging for researchers because they are complex, highly variable, and affect nearly every phase of gene expression. Venom provides an ideal system for studying adaptive evolution as it is a complex phenotype used for prey capture and defense that is subject to strong selective pressures. Snake venom in particular appears to have arisen through rapid evolution, resulting in a conserved set of toxin gene families that are expressed at highly diverse rates across a wide range of taxa. The venom secretion is the result of a fairly straightforward genotype-to-phenotype map, which allows researchers to study expression at various points along the central dogma. To further investigate the evolution of venom gene expression, in Chapter 1 we characterized the venom profile of the Cottonmouth Snake (Agkistrodon piscivorus). We found that across their geographic range, A. piscivorus venom expression consists primarily of proteins in the Phospholipase A2 (PLA2) gene family. In total, we identified nine complete PLA2s tandemly arrayed in the A. piscivorus genome of a female snake collected from the Apalachicola National Forest (ANF) in north Florida, which is more than in any previously characterized North American pit viper. The array contains four expressed PLA2s, one copy of the basic PLA2-K and three copies of the acidic PLA2-A that appear to be the result of gene duplication. This PLA2 region is consistent with the PLA2 arrays of previously annotated hemorrhagic-type rattlesnakes, which lack the characteristic heterodimeric PLA2s in neurotoxic rattlesnake venoms. We found that expression of the four toxin PLA2s varied among individual A. piscivorus, but in all cases PLA2-K was expressed most highly in the venom gland. In Chapter 2, we aimed to determine whether expression variation of the four toxin PLA2s were differentially expressed among the sampled individuals. We collected snakes from the three recognized subspecies of A. piscivorus : The Florida Cottonmouth (A. p. conanti), the Western Cottonmouth (A. p. leucostoma), and the Eastern Cottonmouth (A. p. piscivorus) and performed RNA-sequencing to quantify venom gland expression. We found that only one copy of the acidic PLA2-A1c was differentially expressed between Florida (A. p. conanti) and Continental (A. p. leucostoma and A. p. piscivorus) individuals. This differential expression seemed largely driven by relatively high expression of PLA2-A1c in half of the sampled Florida individuals. Despite the high conservation of the PLA2s gene array across sampled individuals, we did find that this expression variation may be driven by sequence variation found only in the three more high-expression Florida individuals. We identified one synonymous single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in the coding region of Exon 2 of PLA2-A1c that was only present in these individuals. We believe that this SNP could be in linkage with regulatory elements that control PLA2 expression, and thus may explain the increased relative expression. In addition to differential expression among individuals, we all found that PLA2 paralogs are expressed at varying amount within a given individual. In Chapter 3, we aimed to characterize the genomic architecture that may regulate expression of the PLA2 gene family in A. piscivorus. To achieve this, we used ATAC-sequencing of two individuals collected from North Florida (ANF) to characterize accessible chromatin and H3K27ac CUT&RUN sequencing of one individual collected from North Florida (ANF) to identify regions containing active enhancers. We found several regions of interest that may regulate PLA2 expression in A. piscivorus, including open chromatin regions just upstream of each of the four expressed PLA2s that likely contain promoters and large regions of open chromatin downstream of the four expressed PLA2s. We also found three distinct CUT&RUN sequencing peaks associated with active enhancers located between each PLA2-A and their associated unexpressed PLA2-C. These regions are homologous to the third exon of the non-venom expressed PLA2-E, which also shares the associated peak. We used Sequence Capture sequencing reads from 147 individual A. piscivorus to determine whether sequence variation in the identified enhancer and promoter peaks could contribute to PLA2 paralog expression. However, we found that these regions were highly conserved among sampled individuals. Therefore, future works should further investigate the identified peak regions to determine what regulatory elements may be present and contribute to PLA2-expression.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Biological Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Darin R. Rokyta, Professor Directing Thesis; Brian G. Miller, University Representative; Kimberly A. Hughes, Committee Member; Peter Beerli, Committee Member.
